content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of homeless veteran for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. It also establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans receiving the most healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for covered veterans enrolled in the homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system of the Department of Veterans Affairs at six selected locations. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" sets up a program for intensive case management interventions at six locations chosen by the Secretary, including cities with high homeless veteran populations and suburban/rural areas. The Secretary will select locations with strong collaboration between the Department and community organizations providing housing and services for veterans. The program under the "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" provides intensive case management interventions to covered veterans at selected locations to improve housing stability and access to healthcare services. The interventions include assistance with accessing benefits and services to enhance housing stability and healthcare appropriateness. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" program provides case management interventions to improve housing stability and access to healthcare services for covered veterans. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title to ensure appropriate healthcare. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will start the intensive case management program by September 1, 2016. A report on the program's assessments, including types and frequencies of interventions and housing status of veterans, must be submitted by December 1, 2018 to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The intensive case management program under the Department of Veterans Affairs includes assessing veterans' housing status, employment status before and after intervention, use of health care services, and costs incurred by the Department. The Department of Veterans Affairs intensive case management program assesses veterans' use of care services, costs incurred, and number of veterans receiving interventions in different locations. The Department of Veterans Affairs intensive case management program assesses costs incurred for health care services to covered veterans in different locations. SEC. 4. PROGRAM TO IMPROVE RETENTION OF HOUSING BY FORMERLY HOMELESS VETERANS AND VETERANS AT RISK OF BECOMING HOMELESS. The Secretary is required to carry out a program to provide case management services to improve housing retention for formerly homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness through grants. The Secretary will award grants to organizations prioritizing those with experience in providing case management services and transitional housing for homeless individuals. Organizations that voluntarily stop receiving funding for transitional housing services will receive extra priority. The organization can convert a facility from transitional housing to permanent housing meeting housing quality standards. Conversion won't be considered non-compliance with grant terms. The organization can convert a facility from transitional housing to permanent housing without being considered non-compliant with grant terms. Additionally, a clerical amendment was made to the table of sections in the relevant title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to prescribe regulations for a program aimed at improving housing retention for homeless veterans. A report on the program's assessments must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019. The report on the program's assessments must include the percentage of veterans who retained permanent housing, those who did not, and the use of housing by veterans who received case management services. The report on the program's assessments must include the percentage of veterans who retained permanent housing, the use of housing assistance by veterans who received case management services, and the employment status of veterans before and after receiving services. Expansion of housing assistance program for veterans by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38 to expand housing assistance for homeless veterans, those at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families. This includes acquiring shelter, transitioning to permanent housing, and maintaining occupancy in permanent housing. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38 to expand housing assistance for homeless veterans, those at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families by providing permanent or transitional housing. The amendment includes provisions to ensure veterans receiving housing also receive referrals for entitled benefits and services. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs collaborates with various entities to conduct outreach to educate them about the housing needs of veterans. A National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans is established to conduct research and assess program effectiveness. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans is tasked with researching causes of veteran homelessness, evaluating program effectiveness, identifying best practices for housing stabilization and employment assistance, integrating evidence-based policies, and serving as a resource center for homeless veterans and those at risk.
